titleInfo.title: C-Zone Structures of the Human Cardiac Thick Filament by Cryo-Electron Tomography

mods:mods.abstract: Cardiac muscle is special compared with skeletal and smooth muscles that it is supposed to work continuously without any stops. Cardiomyocytes contract during heartbeat cycles that need a delicately controlled force regulation mechanism to adjust the cardiac output according to different physiological conditions. The activation of the thin filaments in the cardiac muscle is controlled by Ca2+ concentration fluctuation in the sarcoplasm, which has been studied thoroughly. However, the studies on the mechanism for controlling the thick filament activation has been limited due to the inadequacy of structural knowledge. The C-zone of vertebrate thick filament is composed of three different molecules, namely, myosin II molecule, myosin binding protein C, and titin. The molecular details of how these proteins interact with each other to control the thick filament activation has not been well understood. In this text, the C-zone molecular structures of the human cardiac thick filament are built through 3-D image reconstruction using cryo-electron tomography. The structures obtained reveal three distinct conformations of myosin II tails that belong to each of the three crowns in the C-zone repeat, respectively. Different conformations of the interacting myosin heads at different levels of activation are also shown in the results and further analyzed by focused classification and refinement. At one crown of the repeating unit, most of the myosin heads are disordered and therefore considered to be activated. At the second crown, many myosin heads assume the classic super-relaxed conformation, which are considered as an inactivate state. At the third crown, some of the "blocked" heads are activated, while some "free" heads are ordered due to the interaction with cMyBP-C. The results also reveal the native structures of the C-terminal domains of cMyBP-C and titin domains within the C-zone. A hierarchical cardiac force regulation mechanism is proposed based on the different conformations of the myosin heads and their interactions with nonmyosin proteins. A mechanical activation mechanism involving a highly dynamic thick filament is further proposed that could provide possible explanations for stretch activation as well as fast contraction and relaxation observed in various types of muscles.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Institute of Molecular Biophysics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Kenneth A. Taylor, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jose R. Pinto, University Representative; Qian Yin, Committee Member; Michelle S. Parvatiyar, Committee Member; Scott Stagg, Committee Member.
